edu.harvard.cs262.GameServer.GameClusterServer

Class GameClusterServer

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.harvard.cs262.GameServer.GameClusterServer.GameClusterServer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    GameServer, java.io.Serializable, java.rmi.Remote

    public class GameClusterServer
extends java.lang.Object
implements GameServer, java.io.Serializable
    The GameClusterServer class contains an implementation of the GameServer interface. It contains a simple leader election algorithm that is tolerant to many types of failure, as well as 100% replication across slave servers.
    Version:
    1.0, April 2014
    Author:
    Twitch Plays Battleship Group
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • GameClusterServer

        public GameClusterServer(GameCommandProcessor processor,
                 Game game)
        This is an instantiation of the most basic type of server necessary to implement this system. This initializes all important instance variables and should be called whenever a new server joins the system.
        Parameters:
        processor - A GameCommandProcessor that will process the commands for this game
        game - A Game that represents the current game

    • Method Detail

      • sendCommand

        public GameSnapshot sendCommand(GameCommand command)
                         throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                                NotMasterException
        When the client wants to play a move on the game, it calls the sendCommand method on the master. If the invoked server is not the master, the NotMasterException is thrown and the client should redirect their call to the proper master. If this is the master, it executes the command issued by the client and updates all peers on the new status of the game.
        Specified by:
        sendCommand in interface GameServer
        Parameters:
        command - A GameCommand sent by the client for the server to execute
        Returns:
        A snapshot that describes what the game looks like now for the client to see the effect of recent move(s)
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.
        NotMasterException - when the command is sent to this server, and this is not the master. Client then knows to find the master.

      • getSnapshot

        public GameSnapshot getSnapshot()
                         throws java.rmi.RemoteException,
                                NotMasterException
        If this is the master, it should have the most up-to-date information on the state of the game. To get info on the game, for the purpose of displaying a surface level screenshot to the user, this method is called. If the invoked server is not the master, the NotMasterException is thrown and the invoking server should redirect the call to the proper master server.
        Specified by:
        getSnapshot in interface GameServer
        Returns:
        A snapshot that describes what the game looks like now for the client to see the effect of recent move(s)
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.
        NotMasterException - when the command is sent to this server, and this is not the master. Client then knows to find the master.

      • setState

        public boolean setState(GameState state)
                 throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        To make sure the game state is consistent and replicated across all slaves, setState is called to update the state of a peer that may be behind. First, the server's frame, how recent its knowledge of the game is, is checked. If the server's frame is behind the frame of the input state, the server's frame and state is updated.
        Specified by:
        setState in interface GameServer
        Parameters:
        state - A GameState the server should update to. The server should forget its idea of the current game state and replace it with state.
        Returns:
        A boolean indicating if the state was properly updated.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.

      • addPeer

        public boolean addPeer(java.util.UUID id,
              GameServer server)
                throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        When a new server joins the system, it should be added to all slaves' peer lists. This method sends the UUID of the new server and a reference to the new server's GameServer object so it can be added to the peer list Hashtable of the called upon server.
        Specified by:
        addPeer in interface GameServer
        Parameters:
        id - The UUID of the new peer server being added to the system
        server - The GameServer that is to be added to the system
        Returns:
        A boolean indicating if the peer server was successfully added
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.

      • removePeer

        public boolean removePeer(java.util.UUID id)
                   throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        When a peer server is down, it should be removed from the peer lists of all currently operating servers. This method implements the removal of that dead peer from the called server's peer list. If the peer is in the peer list at all, it will be removed and a boolean indicating the success and completion of the removal is returned.
        Specified by:
        removePeer in interface GameServer
        Parameters:
        id - The UUID of the peer server that should be removed from the system
        Returns:
        A boolean indicating if the peer server was properly removed.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.

      • setPeers

        public boolean setPeers(java.util.Hashtable<java.util.UUID,GameServer> peers)
                 throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This method is called to inform a server of the peers available in the system. The input Hashtable of UUIDs and GameServers is used as the new set of peers on the called server.
        Specified by:
        setPeers in interface GameServer
        Parameters:

        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.

      • pingServer

        public boolean pingServer()
                   throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Just a method to check that the server is still alive and responsive. If this returns true, the server is responsive. If it throws a RemoteException, we know the server is either deadlocked somehow or is otherwise down.
        Specified by:

      • startLeaderElection

        public java.lang.Object startLeaderElection()
                                     throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        If the master is up and running, return null to indicate that leader election does not need to happen. Otherwise, the server returns its own UUID and a reference to itself.
        Specified by:
        startLeaderElection in interface GameServer
        Returns:
        An object that the elector needs to run the leader election protocol - implementation defined
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.

      • runLeaderElection

        public boolean runLeaderElection()
                          throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        When the master goes down, a new master must be decided and consistently agreed upon by the remaining servers. This is done by making sure that leader election is only done by the server with the smallest known UUID as well as making sure that peer is still alive. Then, the peer with the min UUID looks through all the servers and determines which one is the most up to date with the state of the game. This up-to-date peer is the new master. It then looks through all the known peers and compiles a list of all dead peers and tells the new master which peers are dead and removes them from its peer list. If this method is called during an election, the server pings the elector. If the elector is still up, it returns, otherwise it cancels its current leader election, and begins again.
        Specified by:
        runLeaderElection in interface GameServer
        Returns:
        boolean - true when new leader has been selected and all peers have been notified. False if this server did not serve as elector.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.

      • closeLeaderElection

        public boolean closeLeaderElection(java.util.UUID id,
                          GameServer newLeader)
                            throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        In closing the leader election protocol, this server updates who it believes is the master and prints out the UUID of that new master.
        Specified by:
        closeLeaderElection in interface GameServer
        Parameters:
        id - The UUID of the new master server
        newLeader - The GameServer that is the new master
        Returns:
        A boolean indicating that this server has updated its knowledge of who the master is
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.

      • getMaster

        public GameServer getMaster()
                     throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This method simply asks this server who it believes to be the current master.
        Specified by:
        getMaster in interface GameServer
        Returns:
        Reference to the server that is currently the master.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.

      • setMaster

        public boolean setMaster(GameServer newMaster)
                  throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        This method is used to tell this server who the master is now. If this server is now the master, which would show by the UUIDs being the same, then print to stdout "I am the master" and update instance variable amMaster. Update instance variable master to know who the master is. If for some reason this method breaks halfway through, probably when getting the UUID of the master, then setting the master was not fully performed and the method returns false.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException

      • checkServer

        public boolean checkServer(GameServer s)
        Takes in a reference to a server s and pings it. If the ping causes an error, then it is probably down so return false. If the ping carries out fine, it is probably up and running so return true.

      • isMaster

        public boolean isMaster()
                 throws java.rmi.RemoteException
        Ask if this server thinks it is the master.
        Specified by:
        isMaster in interface GameServer
        Returns:
        Boolean indicating whether or not this server is currently the master.
        Throws:
        java.rmi.RemoteException - when a communication error occurs. Required by extending RMI.

      • checkMaster

        public boolean checkMaster()
        Ask this server if it knows who the master is and check if that master is still up. If this server knows who the master is and that master is running, return true. Otherwise, this server forgets the server it might have known and return false.

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Simply format this server's UUID as an informative string and return it. Return format: "GameClusterServer THIS_UUID".
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object

        public boolean simulateCrash()
        Set internal ''alive'' variable to false. Ping will check this to fake crashing
        Specified by:
